153. Frey, (Mrs. George)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ........................................... Mrs. Geo. Frey
Address ........................................... 131 P.H. Road
Birthplace ....................................... Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ........................................... 1905
Where did you set up housekeeping? ........................................... 16 miles North of Lipton, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? ........................................... River Martelle
For how many people did you prepare meals? ........................................... Seven
How far was it to your nearest store? ........................................... 8.7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? ........................................... Once or twice a year first year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ........................................... Flour sugar tea rolled oats some dried fruit

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ........................................... Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? ........................................... 100 lb or what amount of money you had
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ........................................... around $2.75
How much did you use graham flour? ...........................................
Whole wheat flour? ........................................... Any ground our own in a small grain mill
Was flour milled locally? ........................................... Yes How far away? ........................................... 9.6 miles What year? ........................................... 1930
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ........................................... around .75
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? ........................................... Whole Wheat? ........................................... Farina?
Other? ...........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ........................................... Yes I breed
How did you grind it? ........................................... In a hand mill hand picked to get weed seeds out

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

On 1905 when we came here our breakfast was... [handwritten text not legible]

Rolled oat porridge & toast, dinner was salt pork & potatoes & supper much the same either more porridge or potatoes.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ...1925

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Our first Christmas dinner was just our family Father Mother & four children the eldest 11, 9, 6, 3, 6 months. We had roast beef & gravy, potatoes & mince pie. We came in April & by the time we had a shock up the line we got some breaking done it was late & vegetables didn't grow very well.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had enough to eat the first year we had no crop but Father went out working & made enough to buy food for the winter, he went about 20 miles or more & worked for other farmers & in the winter worked at building in the small towns.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In 1945 when we came back from Buckport was each

Rolled Oat Porridge & Toast, dinner was all pork & potatoes
& a pepper crunch the same within more porridge & potatoes

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu.

Our first Christmas dinner was served our family in December 1946. We had roast beef & gravy, followed by onion pie. We came in April by air. I'm not sure if it was a good meal but it was very well received.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We were always short of food enough to eat. We found year we had no crop but father went out working & made enough to buy food for the winter, he went abroad 30 miles to work & worked for other farmers in the winter worked at building in the small farms.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The most outstanding difference in the variety of foods we have today + the easier methods of cooking them.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still rely on our own home grown vegetables meats & smaller fruits we still have all our own garden vegetables & meat Pork & fowl

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We got most of our groceries in the first years from Selon store in Winnipeg usually in the fall after threshing a big order was made out for winter clothes & dried fruits tea coffee Baking Powder Soda, & all the different dried grocerys we could keep the large store & buying in larger quantities made it a lot cheaper + always 100 lb bag of frozen Lake Superior Herring
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The most noticeable difference is the variety of foods we have today and the easier methods of cooking them.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still rely on our own home grown vegetables much of smaller fruits we still have all our own garden vegetables.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page II more space if needed).

We had many of our groceries in the fall after harvesting a big store in Winnipeg annually in the fall after harvesting a big store was made out for winter clothes, dried fruits, tea, coffee, baking powder, soda, etc., all the different dried grocers we could keep the large store buyer in larger quantities made it a lot cheaper always 100 lb. bag of flour.
